lessons.title: Introduction to HTML
content: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language.
HTML is used to structure content on the web.
Every website begins with HTML.

lessons.title: Links, Images & Media
content: Add links using the <a> tag.
Add images using the tag.
You can embed videos, audio, and interactive components.

lessons.title: Page Layout
content: Use the semantic elements for clean layout: <header>, <section>, <article>, <footer>.
HTML layout is improved with CSS but the skeleton starts here.

courses.title: CSS Modern Design
courses.description: Master modern CSS including flexbox, grid, gradient systems, neumorphism, and dark/light themes.

lessons.title: CSS Basics
content: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
CSS is used to style HTML elements.
Selectors target elements to apply styles.

lessons.title: Flexbox
content: Flexbox is used for responsive layout.
Use display: flex; to activate flexbox.
Common properties: justify-content, align-items, gap.

lessons.title: Grid
content: CSS Grid is a two-dimensional layout system.
Use display: grid; and define rows/columns.
Grid supports auto-placement, spanning, and advanced layout.

lessons.title: Design Systems
content: Modern UI uses layered effects, shadows, and smooth animations.
Dark and light mode require variable-based color systems.
Glassmorphism, gradients, and minimalism are current trends.

courses.title: JavaScript Fundamentals
courses.description: A complete beginner-friendly guide to JavaScript programming.

lessons.title: JavaScript Overview
content: JavaScript adds interactive behavior to websites.
Runs in the browser and powers most modern apps.
JS can be used for full stack development (Node.js).

lessons.title: Variables & Data Types
content: Use let, const to declare variables.
Primitive types include string, number, boolean.
Objects and arrays store structured data.

lessons.title: Functions
content: Functions execute reusable blocks of code.
Arrow functions provide a short syntax.
Functions can accept parameters and return values.

lessons.title: DOM Manipulation
content: The Document Object Model represents the page structure.
Use document.querySelector() to find elements.
Use element.innerHTML, appendChild, classList, etc.
